title: Joni Ernst knocks Hillary Clinton: 'It's not enough to be a woman'
content:
Washington ( CNN ) Turnabout is fair play in Iowa , according to Sen. Joni Ernst .
Ernst , the Iowa Republican whose `` Roast and Ride '' event drew 2016 GOP presidential contenders to the state over the weekend , told CNN 's Dana Bash on `` State of the Union '' that `` it 's not enough to be a woman '' in reference to Hillary Clinton , the Democratic frontrunner .
`` You have to care about women 's issues , '' Ernst said . `` And women 's issues here in Iowa are that we have a strong economy ; we have jobs that our sons and daughters can go off to someday ; we have a great educational system . And women want strong national defense . We want to know that our families are going to be safe . ''
Ernst 's comments were a sharp retooling of a line Clinton had used in campaigning against Ernst in 2014 .
content_original:
Washington (CNN) Turnabout is fair play in Iowa, according to Sen. Joni Ernst.

Ernst, the Iowa Republican whose "Roast and Ride" event drew 2016 GOP presidential contenders to the state over the weekend, told CNN's Dana Bash on "State of the Union" that "it's not enough to be a woman" in reference to Hillary Clinton , the Democratic frontrunner.

Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and freshman Sen. Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, lead a group of bikers during a Roast and Ride hosted by Ernst on Saturday, June 6, in Boone, Iowa. Ernst is hoping the event, which featured a motorcycle tour, a pig roast and speeches from several 2016 presidential hopefuls, becomes an Iowa Republican tradition. Hide Caption 1 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Ernst arrives at the event via motorcycle. Hide Caption 2 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Rick Perry, Republican presidential hopeful and former Texas governor, autographs a picture for a guest. Hide Caption 3 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Mike Huckabee, Republican presidential hopeful and former Arkansas governor, speaks. Hide Caption 4 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Amanda Bork listens to 2016 Republican presidential hopefuls speak. Hide Caption 5 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Perry runs to the stage to speak at the Roast and Ride event. Hide Caption 6 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, speaks. Hide Caption 7 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Mary Kay Arkfeld listens to the speakers. Hide Caption 8 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley takes to the stage during the event. Hide Caption 9 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Former business executive Carly Fiorina speaks. Hide Caption 10 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' A spectator wearing a motorcycle vest emblazoned with a Marine patch listens to the speeches. Hide Caption 11 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Presidential hopeful Dr. Ben Carson greets guests. Hide Caption 12 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida speaks. Hide Caption 13 of 14 Photos: GOP 'Roast and Ride' Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker speaks from the stage. Hide Caption 14 of 14

"You have to care about women's issues," Ernst said. "And women's issues here in Iowa are that we have a strong economy; we have jobs that our sons and daughters can go off to someday; we have a great educational system. And women want strong national defense. We want to know that our families are going to be safe."

Ernst's comments were a sharp retooling of a line Clinton had used in campaigning against Ernst in 2014.
